g.text: 3.1. Synthesis and X-ray Crystal Analysis of H
L14 was synthesized by a cyclization reaction between 1,4-diaminobutane

raction data were collected on a Bruker D8 QUEST

All employed reagents and solvents were of analytical grade. The complexes were obtained by
L14 receptor with appropriate meal salts, CuCO
O in a molar ratio 1:1. The carbonate insoluble fraction was removed by Ô¨Åltration.
The solution was concentrated and acetone was added to precipitate the metal complexes, which were
separated by Ô¨Åltration and dried at 50
The thermogravimetric analyses (TGAs) of the metal complexes were carried out with a
Perkin‚ÄìElmer Pyris 1 TGA apparatus at a heating rate of 5
min for CuL14 and MnL14, and
min for FeL14 in a temperature range of 25 to 800
atmosphere at a Ô¨Çow rate of
min. Spectrumevaluations were performed using the Pyris version 11.1.1.0492 software package.
The infrared spectra were recorded in the spectral range between 4000 and 250 cm
FIRS Spectrometer Frontier instrument. A total of 32 scans were performed.
Raman spectra were obtained using a HORIBA LabRam HR Evolution Raman microscope at room
temperature. AHe‚ÄìNe laser was employed with an energy of 633 nmfrom20 mWto 100 mWand a slit
m. The X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained on a Perkin‚ÄìElmer PHI 5100 model
torr. All the spectra were corrected to alkyl type
carbon C1s (285.0 eV) and Ô¨Åtted by applying a Tougard baseline and a Gaussian‚ÄìLorentzian function
